title: What happen to the amount of enzyme at the end of a chemical reaction? Why does it happens? - Quora

response.answer_text: Nothing. And “nothing” happens because enzymes are catalysts. Catalysts, by definition, are “things” that improve the rate of a chemical reaction without having been changed at the end the a reaction. Of course they are changed during the steps in the chemical reaction, but at the end, the catalyst has been reverted to the initial state. That means that a catalyst (including enzymes) are not used up by the chemical reaction they catalyze.
